articles.author: Amber Dance
articles.title: Sex, immunity, and the brain - Big Think
articles.description: Boys are four times as likely as girls to develop autism. Girls are nearly twice as likely to experience depression. The immune system may be a player in these and other brain-health disparities.

articles.author: Nick Summerfield
articles.title: Man diagnosed with bowel cancer reveals words that changed his life - Metro.co.uk
articles.description: I was 33, getting looser stools, constipation, and diarrhoea - I also noticed blood in my poo.
articles.content:
I called my GP, and was offered an appointment that very same day (Picture: Nick Summerfield)
I never in a million years dreamt thiswould ever be my story. Butit turns outthat young people get bowel… [+8655 chars]

articles.author: Karin Söderlund Leifler
articles.title: How the ear may inform the brain when hearing is impaired - Phys.org
articles.description: A cochlear signal, the exact role of which has been unclear since its discovery around 70 years ago, probably gives the brain information on whether the ear is functioning normally or not. This is the conclusion of a study from Linköping University, Sweden.
articles.content: A cochlear signal, the exact role of which has been unclear since its discovery around 70 years ago, probably gives the brain information on whether the ear is functioning normally or not. This is th… [+3757 chars]

articles.author: Neuroscience News
articles.title: Trusting Others Over Self: Infants' Unusual Bias Towards Outside Observations - Neuroscience News
articles.description: This "altercentric bias" might facilitate learning during a time when the infant's ability to interact with the environment is limited.
articles.content:
Summary: Infants tend to trust others’ observations more than their own.
Studying 8- and 12-month-old infants, the researchers found that younger infants prioritized an animated character’s attentio… [+6260 chars]
